utterances: Tradition in this country.
It goes all the way.
And what a success story, as well.
It certainly was.
So - but Bill Richardson obviously, clearly wanted to be secretary of state.
You know, first of all, because he also wanted to be vice president and president.
And he was quoted as saying that he was disappointed with the Hillary Clinton pick.
But - and one question, a Hispanic questioner at the press conference today asked Barack Obama if this was a consolation prize and, of course, Barack Obama said, absolutely that's not the case.
But you know, a lot of people felt that, you know, he wanted bigger stuff.
He has a, you know, globe-trotting reputation.
But you know something?
He could also be a very good salesman, a good cheerleader for the economic policies of Barack Obama.
We have some people on the line who think they know the answer to today's trivia question.
And again, because of the run-off forced in Georgia, because Saxby Chambliss, the Republican, just failed to get over 50 percent in the general election on the 4th of November.
Well, what other two senators lost re-election bids this time around partly because of third-party candidates?
And let's see if we can get Ben on the line, and Ben is calling us from Roslindale in Massachusetts
Hi, Neal.
Thanks for taking my call.
Go ahead, please.
I'm going to have to go with Ted Stevens in Alaska.
I'm pretty sure about that one, and John Sununu in New Hampshire would be my other choice.
Your neighboring state of New Hampshire.
Well, Ted Stevens is exactly right.
Ted Stevens only lost by about 3,500 votes, and there was a third-party candidate who got 13,000 votes.
His name was Bob Bird of the Alaska Independence Party.
Ted Stevens did go down in part because of a third-party candidate.
But in New Hampshire Jean Shaheen did a get a majority of the vote.
It wasn't a third-party candidate who hurt John Sununu.
Ben, you get a half a no prize.
I'm not sure what that's worth.
Great.
Well, I might end up re-gifting it this Christmas.
Instead of the Nobel Prize, just the no prize.
Just the no prize.
And let's get Mike on line, Mike with from Golden Valley in Minnesota.
Hi.
Well, I guess hearing the first caller changed my answer on one of them for the second, that's Ted Stevens.
For the second one, I'm going to say Gordon Smith.
Ding, ding, ding.
Congratulations, Joe.
And Gordon Smith is correct, too.
There was a Constitution Party candidate named Dave Brownlow, who got 87,000 votes, and Gordon Smith only lost by 50,000 votes to Jeff Merkley.
So the two answers are Ted Steven of Alaska and Gordon Smith in Oregon.
And Mike that was a deft change of answer there in midstream.
What I can say?
You know, I'm just taking advantage of the situation.
All right.
Keep listening, Mike, and enjoy your no prize.
Oh yeah.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
They can share that.
They can share that no prize.
Yes, it's a - and here's an email that - just about the situation in Georgia yesterday.

My sister voted in a church - this from Rebecca in Brattleboro, Vermont - my sister voted in a church outside Brunswick, Georgia, yesterday and reports a table full of Chambliss literature inside the polling place.
No Martin material to be seen.
Interesting, because Senator Obama, now former Senator Obama, kept open all of his 25 offices, I think, in Georgia to try to mount a very vigorous effort on behalf of Jim Martin.
It was clear that the Republican Party wanted this.
I don't know if they wanted it more than the Democrats, but think of all - everybody who came down, that they spent a ton of money, both sides did.
They really wanted it.

What's most interesting, switching subjects for one second, about the Bill Richardson choice, I think the real question is what's wrong with Chris Dodd, Mike Gravel and Dennis Kucinich, because they are only the Democrats that didn't get appoint - I mean, you have Joe Biden.
Yet.
Yes, it's early.
That's true.
Yes, it's true.
There's, you know, there's transportation, HUD.
There's a lot of things left.
But, you know something.
I mean, I remember Richard Nixon naming George Romney, who was a rival for the nomination, to the Cabinet in '68, but I don't remember any president picking this many rivals as part of his team.
It's very fascinating to watch.
And yet, also some pretty interesting decisions yet to be made by the governors of Illinois and New York to replace Senators Obama and Clinton.
That's right.
Barack Obama's term would be up in 2010 anyway.
But Governor Rod Blagojevich does need to make an appointment, a replacement.

There are so many people on the list: Jesse Jackson Jr., congressman Danny Davis, Jan Schakowsky is a congresswoman who wants it; Tammy Duckworth's name has been mentioned, but - although she's also mentioned as veteran affairs in the Obama Cabinet.
And in New York, I think, everybody.
Everybody.
Every single person in the state of New York.
Exactly.
Clyde Haberman had this great column in the New York Times the other day about naming - we need, you know, a gay Roman Catholic upstate lesbian - every constituency possible.
So, David, I don't - you don't envy David Patterson, but Hillary Clinton says she's not going to resign the Senate until the Senate confirms her.
Obviously, that would be until mid to late January.
And if that's the case, then we have at least another month and a half to speculate on who this nominee will be.
Let the fundraising begin in Florida, where the incumbent Republican senator, Mel Martinez, said he will not be running for re-election in two years' time.
He wants to spend more time with the family.
The fact that his approval ratings are in the 30s has nothing to do with it.
Well, that has a lot to do with that.
If I got a nickel for everybody who said, I want to, you know, spend more time with my family.

But the interesting thing is, as the Democrats are elevating one of the most prominent Hispanic Democrats, Bill Richardson, Mel Martinez, one of the most prominent Hispanic Republicans, is taking himself out of the mix.
What's also interesting is that, of course, if he resigns early, Charlie Crist, the Republican governor, could name a replacement.
And the name of Jeb Bush has come up as a possible candidate.
He has not ruled it out.
I always thought he didn't want to come to Washington.
He'd rather have a power base in Florida.
But if he were to be the senator, that would be very interesting because eventually, you know, he could run for president.
We haven't had a Bush running for president since 2004.
Really, you know, it's been a while to have somebody new in there.
I've been following this stuff on my daily blog.
It can be found at npr.org.
What's it called, by the way?
Political Junkie, thank you.
What a name.

As we go back also on those governors being appointed to positions in Washington, Cabinet positions, there will be a new female governor and, well, a Republican, actually, gets elevated in Arizona to replace Democrat Janet Napolitano.
Right.
Actually, both governors, the new governors will be females even though Janet Napol's being replaced by Jan Brewer.
It's a party change.
Jan Brewer is - there's no lieutenant governor in Arizona; she's secretary of state, and she's very, very conservative on social issues, on taxes, on abortion.
So ideologically, it's a big change in Arizona.
In New Mexico, New Mexico will get its first female governor, Diane Denish, who's the lieutenant governor, who's already been planning to run for governor in 2010.
Because Bill Richardson was term-limited, so she will be elevated to the governorship.
Ken Rudin, NPR's political editor, our Political Junkie who joins us here on the program every Wednesday in Studio 3A.
Did you mention the blog?
I've heard that there is a new blog at npr.org.
It's called the Political Junkie.
Yes, you can read that and well, look for old columns that you can just kick dirt over now because that is dead as a doornail.
Ken Rudin is going to be with us.
We're going to be joined by Mike Huckabee.
You know, we got enough talk show host competition already.
Now, the former Arkansas governor and Republican presidential candidate is in the talk show business.
He's also on some people's short list for presidential Republican nomination in four years' time.
So, stay with us.
We're going to be talking about the future of the Republican Party and, well, its time in the electoral wilderness.
Stay with us.

This is Talk of the Nation.

Ken Rudin is still with us, NPR's political editor, our Political Junkie, now NPR's newest blogger.

Two surprising names came out on top of the Iowa caucuses last January.
One went on to be elected president of the United States.
One now hosts a TV talk show.
Though to be fair, many talk about former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee among the strong possibilities for the Republican nomination for president four years from now.

For the rest of this hour, we'll focus on the future of the Republican Party with Governor Huckabee, He also has a new book out titled, ""Do the Right Thing."" And we'd like to hear from Republicans in our audience today about the future of the GOP and the lessons of 2008.
Does the party need to moderate social views to win back independents and some Democrats?
Or does it need to stick to the values embraced by the party base and the party platform?

Go to npr.org and click on Talk of the Nation.
Mike Huckabee joins us today from the studios of member station WDET in Detroit.
And Governor, nice to have you back on Talk of the Nation.
Thank you.
Great to be back.
And I have to ask you about the big political news of the day.
What do you make of Bill Richardson shaving his beard?
Bill is a great, great guy, and I think with or without the beard, he's still going to be a very effective Cabinet secretary.
Very smart man, probably one of the most experienced people and could frankly have served in any one of about a dozen positions and would have done very, very well.
